Have like 1300-1500 hrs on ps4 as well as 300 here on pc. Largely the same issues. Very imbalanced game, especially the killers, in general. The way that you have to play to win sort of deliberately creates a toxic environment at high ranks. Running the same stale perks and killers is encouraged, and killers often feel like they have to resort to scummy tactics and meta perks to win (which they do), which leads to complimentary reaction from survivors, sort of creating an endless cycle of toxic behavior and gameplay, supported by the devs' bad balance decision. In a sense, this is a game that specifically encourages toxic behavior. You are not designed to win and play fair at high ranks of people of the same skill as you. 

The map design in this game is mostly completely horrible. Roughly 25%~ of maps are balanced equally, the other 75% often weigh heavily towards one side or the other, with survivors having more maps in their favor. 

 Devs are lazy (they have said on stream they only work when they feel like it), don't accept almost any feedback from experienced players, and are mostly bad themselves. Pair that with DbD acquiring licenses like Super Smash bros just to increase their fanbase and solidify their monopoly on the market for now. This leads to them being able to ignore most serious problems this game has, because they have no competition, which is why the quality of this game is generally pretty low. 

And none of this even takes into account the myriad of technical problems. Collision is bad, hitboxes don't work half the time, rubberbanding is common, sound is completely broken and audio occlusion doesn't exist. The game kind of works when it wants to, and it's possible for either killer or survivor to lose just because of this game's lackluster technical performance sometimes. 

TL;DR Bad game/map design, lazy and obstinate devs. Would not recommend. Like an absuvie relationship more than a game, tbh.

First of all you're going to grind for a couple of hundred hours to unlock all the worthwhile perks, both for killers and survivors, you'll need them. Then you'll spend another hundred hours learning and understanding how each perk and item and add-on and offering complements or conflicts with one another, they're important, especially for some killers. 

Now, the game might get good... right? Yeah, sure, good luck with that.

Hope you don't mind getting disconnected every couple of games with increasing penalties that lock you out of playing the game despite your internet being fine, because "you're ruining the experience for the other players". This is the single most frustrating aspect of the game and it's completely outside of your control. BHVR won't address the issue, they're far too busy pumping out more content and cosmetics, and the community is more than eager to damn you for it.

There's a broken matchmaking system that pairs you with or against players that have several thousands of hours experience in the game or just started the game yesterday and have no idea what they're doing. Early on every other killer will camp you on the hook and tunnel you out of the game without letting you do anything. This is fine, it's a play style many people complain about but is also encouraged and justified by a lot of the game's community, some of the killers are designed with that play style in mind. You don't see it as often in the higher ranks, but it does happen. Put up with it, you wouldn't want to ruin the game experience for others after all. 

There's some toxicity here, the game has that reputation, but I don't feel like it's particularly worse than any other online game. Some players will realize you're new and try and help you during the match and offer tips when its over, others will abandon you and chew you out for being useless or complain that you did something they wanted to do. Avoid the forums as much as you can however, the regulars are nauseating in their blind devotion to BHVR. 

This is a pretty unrewarding and frustrating game to get into and I would only recommend it with a group of friends to play with frequently, at least until you get the basics of the game down. If you endure, you'll learn what you need to learn and get used to not caring about what you can't control. If you're mostly on your own however, do yourself a favor and avoid this game and find a better product and developer to support.

Dead by Daylight is an incredibly fun-and frustrating-game.  Overall there are many pros and cons for the game but ultimately for the price I would absolutely recommend giving it a try.  It can be slow going when you are first learning how to play but you are also rewarded as you get better.  

The asymmetrical aspect of killer versus survivor makes it difficult to have a real sense of balance for all parties, and that's okay.  Whether you fill the role of killer or survivor, you can play to win as a team, be underhanded to be the last one standing, or just fool around and enjoy yourself.  There are dozens or hundreds of different ways to play the game and the DLC is not required to have good variety.  However, if you want to try different characters, you can earn in game currency to purchase the original game characters without spending real money. 

Some of the downsides to this game include the slow start-learning the many facets of this game can take awhile and be a bit frustrating but taking your time to do the tutorial, watch guides, or even play on the opposite side can help you learn better.  Also, a regular complaint is the matchmaking/queue times which can result in matches that are unbalanced and not very fun-playing with friends can make this more bearable as a survivor, but as a killer it can be quite annoying.  The final major issue people have with Dead by Daylight is the lack of balance-various perks and abilities can affect the gameplay subtly or majorly, and some tactics can be quite cheesy and feel unfair.  I would urge anyone who feels that way to see it as another challenge and keep practicing to learn how to play against that.  

Finally, the developers of this game are incredibly dedicated and talented individuals who have provided a unique experience that they continue to update and make improvements on, while listening to members of the community for feedback and criticism.
